creditline: Proceeds from the 2012 Minneapolis Print and Drawing Fair
description: St. Francis with beard and halo, kneeling with PL knee on a flat rock, arms outstretched, wearing a patched robe; tiny crucified Christ on X-shaped cross in URC, with dotted lines extending from Christ's nail wounds to Francis' hands and feet; detailed landscape with buildings, trees and road; reading seated figure behind Francis in middle ground
inscription:
Signature, Date and Inscription

Inscribed in lower margin: [Signasti Domine Seruum Tuum Franciscum Signis Redemptionis Nostre\']

LRC on mount, in pencil: [Vol 18 5 / P. 21]; top center on mount, in pencil: [86 Y]
provenance:
William Cavendish, 2nd Duke of Devonshire (d. 1729), Chatsworth (cf. Lugt 718-719)
by descent to Andrew Cavendish, 11th Duke of Devonshire, Chatsworth (until 1985); Trustees of the Chatsworth Settlement; sale, Christie's, London, December 5, 1985, no. 130, for Â£5,940, to Colnaghi; [Colnaghi, London, 1985-at least 1986]. private collection. [Adrian Eeles, London; in 2011]; [C.G. Boerner, New York; 2012; sold to MIA]
signed: bottom center on stone in foreground, in the plate: [Camillo procacino / Bol. Invent: Incid: / 1593]
text: The Counter-Reformation painter Camillo Procaccini was also an influential and innovative printmaker. He executed very few etchings-probably just six-over his lifetime, but the works are noteworthy for their ambition, bold technique, and scale. Saint Francis of Assisi Receiving the Stigmata is perhaps Procaccini's most accomplished etching. Executed in Milian in 1593, it is a powerful portrayal of Saint Francis' violent vision, combining compelling naturalistic detail with evocative spiritual mysticism. This particular impression is arguably the best surviving example of the rare print known today; it was formerly in the celebrated print collection of the Dukes of Devonshire (Chatsworth).
title: Saint Francis of Assisi Receiving the Stigmata
